webTitle: Fast flu: real-time influenza data

fields.standfirst:
Sometimes, it can be hard for health agencies to see national patterns in flu viruses, let alone international ones. Google Flu Trends is an attempt to make that data available in real-time using flu-related search queries. Despite the fact that not everyone that searches flu online has the virus, Google has found a strong correlation between symptoms and searches. This video explains how they do it. You can explore maps for global flu trends, see changes over time and download the data yourself here.

• More visualisations in this series
fields.headline: Fast flu: real-time influenza data
fields.trailText: Sometimes, it can be hard for health agencies to see national patterns in flu viruses, let alone international ones. Google Flu Trends is an attempt to make that data available in real-time using flu-related search queries.

webTitle: Guardian Camera Club: Bruce Wayne's portfolio

fields.standfirst:
A review of Bruce Wayne's portfolio.

The first impression is of beautiful gelatine prints, but these images were made with a Canon G9 compact camera. The tonality of the images is outstanding, 'Life cycle 1', with its quirky point of view, works beautifully, and has a strong sense of the potential growth of this plant. '2' has a strong and dynamic diagonal construction; '3' is more complex, the stamens beautifully rendered. The soft structure of the petals makes for a detailed texture in '4'; by '5' we see the decay and desiccation starting, only the line on the wall behind is a distraction. '6' sees the inevitable end, it's an ethereal image, the background providing perhaps too much context. This is a lovely series, a time line, and all the better for the combination of camera and post processing used
fields.headline: Guardian Camera Club: Bruce Wayne's portfolio
fields.trailText: A review of Bruce Wayne's portfolio

tags.bio:
Jason Burke is the south Asia correspondent of The Guardian and The Observer newspapers.

In more than a decade as a staff correspondent with the papers Burke has reported on a wide range of subjects in countries from Algeria to Cambodia, from Uzebkistan to Zimbabwe. 

Based in Pakistan from 1998 to 2002,  reporting from Afghanistan under the Taliban and during the war of 2001, he has returned to both Pakistan and Afghanistan many times since. Burke has also worked extensively in the Middle East, reporting from Iraq before, during and after the war of 2003. He has specialised in conflict, terrorism and Islamic militancy.

Currently based in New Delhi, he covers a wide range of social, political and cultural topics across South Asia. He is a regular commentator on television and radio.

Burke is the author of Al-Qaeda: the true story of radical Islam, published in 2003, which analysed the role of the militant group and its ideology and described the complex reality of modern Islamic radicalism. A second book, On The Road To Kandahar, was published in 2006. Burke speaks good French, average Hindi and Urdu and terrible Arabic.
Saad Hammadi is an investigative journalist in Dhaka who has covered Bangladesh for the Guardian and The Christian Science Monitor
